stories.name: Amazon MGM Asks Oregon Theater To End Melania Run
stories.summary: The Lake Theater & Cafe in Lake Oswego, Oregon, says Amazon MGM asked it to stop screening the Brett Ratner documentary Melania after the venue advertised the film with cheeky marquee lines such as “Does Melania wear Prada? Find out Friday!” and “To defeat your enemy, you must know them. Melania starts Friday.” Manager Jordan Perry posted that “the higher ups” at Amazon were upset and that Sunday would be the film’s last day; the marquee was later changed to messages noting Amazon had called and that showings were canceled. Perry said he booked the film partly as a joke and to fill a slow week, but the decision drew heavy pushback from patrons, numerous emails and voicemails, and negative online reviews, and attendance was modest. The episode highlights tensions between a major distributor’s marketing control and a small independent cinema’s irreverent programming choices, and several outlets note the documentary has been controversial, costly for its distributor, and poorly reviewed.
keyPoints: Amazon MGM Studios paid $40 million for the rights to produce and distribute Brett Ratner’s Melania (reported as a 2025 acquisition).
Theater manager Jordan Perry warned the Lake Theater & Cafe might be put on Amazon’s “black list,” which he said could affect the venue’s access to future Amazon releases such as Project Hail Mary.

Reported production and marketing figures: Melania reportedly cost $40 million to make and $35 million to market; it earned about $7 million on its opening weekend and holds roughly a 6% score on Rotten Tomatoes.

stories.name: Regional Roundup: Forums, Legislation, Fisheries Decline
stories.summary: Rep. David Rouzer (R‑NC) will host his annual U.S. Service Academy Information Forum on April 25 in Southport to guide Seventh District students, parents and educators through the two‑step nomination and admissions process; interested participants must RSVP by email. Alaska lawmakers returned to Juneau facing decisions on funding failing schools and state infrastructure and will debate Governor Dunleavy’s proposals on new taxes, changes to the Permanent Fund Dividend, energy development and public safety as they seek a sustainable fiscal path. The Indiana House approved HB1343 to allow the adjutant general to establish a National Guard “military police force” with statewide arrest, search and policing powers; the measure now moves to the Senate amid concerns it could enable politicized deployments. Recent sittings of the UK House of Commons covered a broad agenda — including Holocaust Memorial Day, youth unemployment, the British Indian Ocean Territory Bill, prison capacity, pensions, police reform and multiple ministerial questions — signaling active parliamentary business. Regional reporting republished in local outlets documents a long, steep decline in Pacific halibut with ecological and economic impacts on fishing communities, while major outlets continue to publish categorized political coverage accompanied by standard legal and market‑data disclaimers.
keyPoints: Rep. David Rouzer’s forum will open registration at 9 a.m. with the program from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. and will be held at the Brunswick Energy and Education Center, 8520 River Road SE, Southport; representatives from all five U.S. service academies — including the U.S. Coast Guard Academy — will attend.

U.S. Sens. Thom Tillis (R‑N.C.) and Richard Blumenthal (D‑Conn.) recently introduced the bipartisan National Law Enforcement Officers Remembrance, Support and Community Outreach Act to create a formal Interior Department program to support community outreach, public education and officer safety/wellness initiatives via grants to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund.

House Bill 1343, which passed the Indiana House and now goes to the Senate, explicitly authorizes the adjutant general to establish a National Guard “military police force” whose members may carry firearms and exercise statewide arrest, search and other police powers — a provision critics warn could enable politicized deployments.

stories.name: Pinterest Fires Engineers Over Layoff Tracker Amid Cuts
stories.summary: Pinterest announced plans to cut about 15% of its workforce—roughly 700 roles—as part of a restructuring to reallocate resources to AI-focused teams, shrink office space, with changes expected to be completed by Sept. 30. Leadership declined to publish a broad list of affected employees, citing privacy concerns. Two engineers wrote scripts that monitored internal tools such as Slack to flag deactivated accounts and shared the results; Pinterest said they improperly accessed confidential information, violated policy and breached colleagues’ privacy, and the company fired them. CEO Bill Ready defended the dismissals at a companywide town hall, calling the actions “obstructionist” while saying healthy dissent is welcome but there is a line for conduct that undermines the company. The incident has provoked debate over transparency and employee rights and has been framed as emblematic of a broader shift toward employer control amid AI-driven job cuts in the tech industry.
keyPoints: Pinterest told investors the restructuring will cost between $35 million and $45 million, according to an 8‑K filing.
Pinterest said investment in AI-related headcount contributed to a 15% year‑over‑year increase in non‑GAAP operating expenses, an increase of about $543 million.

At the companywide town hall, CEO Bill Ready told employees they should consider looking for another job if they are 'working against the direction of the company,' framing the firings as necessary amid a 'critical moment.'

stories.name: AT&T, Amazon Forge Nationwide Satellite-Fiber Network
stories.summary: On Feb. 4, 2026 AT&T and Amazon announced a strategic “fiber-to-space” partnership pairing AT&T’s terrestrial fiber and customer relationships with Amazon Leo satellite connectivity and deep integration of AWS cloud services. The agreement will migrate major AT&T workloads to AWS hybrid cloud (including AWS Outposts), link AWS data centers with high-capacity AT&T fiber, and use Amazon Leo to expand fixed broadband and enterprise services while boosting resilience for FirstNet public-safety connectivity. The companies say the combined connectivity-plus-compute model is designed to eliminate domestic dead zones and support advanced AI applications at scale, positioning the alliance as a counterweight to SpaceX’s Starlink. The announcement rattled niche satellite-to-phone providers—AST SpaceMobile and Globalstar shares dropped sharply—and both firms said they will provide more details at Mobile World Congress in early March. Amazon Leo is also preparing a 32‑satellite launch with Arianespace targeted for Feb. 12 to help build out the constellation that will underpin the deal.
keyPoints: AT&T plans to use Amazon’s Q Developer AI software to expedite the migration of some workloads to AWS as part of the partnership.

AT&T Business Senior Vice President Shawn Hakl said, “By pairing our expanding fiber infrastructure with AWS’s cloud capabilities, and through our collaboration to deliver the infrastructure of the future by connecting data centers, we’re creating a more resilient, scalable, and intelligent connectivity ecosystem.”
Amazon Leo is the rebranded commercial wing of Project Kuiper and operates as a separate Amazon business unit.

stories.name: Will Arnett Says SmartLess Cut Famous Comedian
stories.summary: Will Arnett said on The Romesh Ranganathan Show on Jan. 26 that he and his SmartLess co‑hosts Jason Bateman and Sean Hayes recently cut a 'very famous comedian' after roughly 10 minutes of recording, calling the guest a 'f---ing rank a--hole.' Arnett declined to name the comedian on air, joking listeners would be 'blown away' and quipping, 'How did you get Bill Cosby!' He also described a separate episode in which a female comedian asked them not to air her already‑recorded appearance because she was 'up‑and‑coming,' a request the hosts weighed against production costs. Arnett's remarks have prompted online speculation about the guests' identities and follow recent SmartLess friction, including criticism of a Jason Bateman exchange with Charli XCX about having children. Launched in 2020, SmartLess remains a top‑ranked, Golden Globe‑nominated podcast with major distribution deals and industry recognition, which helps explain why discarded episodes and guest drama draw attention.
keyPoints: SmartLess was ranked sixth in the U.S. by Apple in 2025, placing it among the most‑listened podcasts nationally.

In 2023 the hosts and SmartLess Media struck a reported $100 million deal with SiriusXM that granted the company exclusive rights for three years to distribute and sell ads for the podcast and other SmartLess Media programs.
SmartLess was nominated in the Golden Globes' inaugural best podcast category but lost to Good Hang With Amy Poehler.

stories.name: Fallout Finale Reveals Major Lore; Season 3 Confirmed
stories.summary: The Fallout Season 2 finale resolved several major arcs and delivered key revelations: Hank (Kyle MacLachlan) is exposed as the architect of Shady Sands’ destruction and the creator of a brainwave-control device, and Overseer Steph (Annabel O’Hagan) is revealed as his pre-war wife and Enclave liaison. Hank ultimately activates the apparatus on himself, erasing his memories, while Lucy kills the surviving politician whose head had powered the machine. The Ghoul restores Robert House, receives a Pip-Boy that directs him to his family’s cryogenic tubes—which are found empty except for a postcard to Colorado—and then strikes out on his own; elsewhere Macaulay Culkin’s Legate assumes Legion leadership and tensions between the Legion and the NCR set up a large-scale conflict. A post-credits beat reveals Brotherhood of Steel blueprints for Liberty Prime, explicitly teeing up a much bigger Season 3 threat. Amazon and producers have confirmed Season 3 is in pre-production with filming slated to begin May 1, 2026; meanwhile a Bethesda/Prime countdown tied to the show revealed only behind-the-scenes footage, not the rumored game remasters. Critics and fans largely praised Season 2’s writing and performances, though some reviewers found the finale narratively hollow or uneven.
keyPoints: Hank claims he successfully miniaturised the brainwave-control apparatus and says he has covert operatives scattered across the Wasteland who could continue his plan.
The politician whose severed head powered the machine is identified as Denise Welch; in her final moments she pleads with Lucy to end her life, and Lucy complies.
Fallout Season 2 became the highest-rated live-action video game adaptation on Rotten Tomatoes when it premiered, strengthening the series’ reputation as one of Prime Video’s biggest hits.

stories.name: Amazon makes Alexa+ free for US Prime
stories.summary: Amazon has moved Alexa+ (Alexa Plus), its generative-AI overhaul of Alexa, out of early access and opened it across the U.S., available on Echo devices, the Alexa app, and Alexa.com. The assistant is rebuilt on large language models from Amazon Nova and Anthropic to enable more natural, contextual conversations and “agentic” actions like booking restaurants, ordering takeout, scheduling rides, and managing calendars. U.S. Prime members get unlimited access to the full Alexa+ experience at no additional charge, while non-Prime users can try a limited free chat or pay $19.99 per month for full access—making Prime the cheaper path for most customers. Amazon says testers used Alexa+ roughly twice as much as classic Alexa and highlights deeper Q&A, planning, and multi-step handling, but some reviewers note that many of the most useful features are now behind a paywall and remain skeptical about how broadly people will rely on agentic capabilities. The rollout positions Alexa+ as a mass-market, LLM-powered assistant and a direct competitor to other premium AI subscriptions and upcoming assistant upgrades from rival platforms.
keyPoints: Prime members can enable Alexa+ simply by saying "Alexa, upgrade to Alexa+" or by signing into their Amazon account on Alexa.com — a voice-command activation path Amazon highlights for easy access.

Amazon emphasizes Alexa+’s integration with Amazon services and hardware — including Ring cameras — and says the assistant can help users get more value from Prime benefits like Amazon Photos, Prime Video, and Amazon Music.

Amazon Prime is priced at $14.99 per month or $139 per year in the U.S., making Prime a cheaper route to full Alexa+ access than subscribing to Alexa+ standalone; Amazon also offers a 30‑day free Prime trial for first-time customers.

stories.name: Renters Reportedly Embrace Rent-Now Pay-Later Services
stories.summary: So-called “rent now, pay later” services have grown as rents have climbed—nearly 28% over the past five years, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics—and many renters with uneven paychecks are using them to avoid front-loading the month’s housing cost. Companies such as Flex, Livble and Affirm typically pay landlords up front while renters repay in installments, which users say can ease monthly cash-flow problems for lower-income and gig-economy workers. Consumer advocates counter that these products often function like short-term loans, adding subscription fees and other charges that can amount to very high effective interest rates and deepen financial strain. The tradeoff is illustrated by a renter who paid a $14.99 monthly fee plus 1% of $1,850 in rent (about $33 total) to split his payments for convenience. With roughly 109 million Americans renting and many households classified as cost-burdened by the Census Bureau, the trend is raising questions about whether these services provide meaningful relief or introduce new risks that may warrant consumer protections.
keyPoints: The renter quoted in the articles, Kellen Johnson, said “It was an expense that I was incurring, but I went ahead as it was more convenient,” and the articles note he previously worked as an independently contracted delivery driver for Amazon and now drives for senior citizens in Sacramento, California.

The Census Bureau’s 2024 estimate cited in the reporting found a large share of renter households pay 30% or more of their income on rent (the definition of being “cost-burdened”), a condition the articles say makes it difficult for those households to save or invest for the future.

The reporting frames the roughly 109 million Americans who rent as roughly one-third of the U.S. population—about 33% of the country’s ~333 million people—underscoring how many people could be affected by these products.

stories.name: Reports: Israeli fire kills Palestinians despite Gaza ceasefire
stories.summary: Palestinian media reported that at least two people, including 3-year-old Iyad al-Rubaiya, were killed in Gaza—the child was said to have been hit by gunfire from an Israeli Navy boat in al-Mawasi, and 22-year-old Ramadan Dardouna was reported killed in Jabalia. Other people were wounded in the incidents, and Gaza’s Hamas-run health ministry said hospitals had received four wounded and the bodies of three people killed over the past 24 hours, plus two earlier deaths. The Israeli military has not commented on these specific reports, though it has previously said strikes are in response to ceasefire violations. Details remain unverified and accounts vary by outlet.
keyPoints: The body of 3-year-old Iyad al-Rubaiya was reportedly taken to Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis after the al-Mawasi incident.
The 22-year-old Ramadan Dardouna’s body was reportedly brought to Shifa Hospital in Gaza City after he was killed in Jabalia.
Some outlets additionally reported that a 40-year-old man was killed in the al-Mawasi incident and his body was also taken to Nasser Hospital.

stories.name: US January Manufacturing PMI Rises To 52.6
stories.summary: The ISM manufacturing PMI for January unexpectedly showed expansion at 52.6, well above estimates around 48.5. US futures rose modestly, with S&P 500 futures up about 0.3%, Nasdaq 100 futures up 0.2% and Dow futures gaining nearly 200 points, as investors shifted focus to a heavy corporate earnings slate. Earnings-driven moves included Eli Lilly jumping more than 6% in premarket trading after beating estimates and issuing upbeat 2026 guidance, Alphabet and Qualcomm ticking higher, while AMD plunged nearly 9% and Uber fell about 7.5%, with mixed results from Amgen and Chubb. Reuters noted analysts lifted earnings growth expectations to roughly 11% for the December quarter even as consumer confidence hit an 11½-year low and a partial federal shutdown delayed some employment data. Traders are watching upcoming macro prints — including the ADP employment report and ISM manufacturing readings — and concerns about AI-driven disruption have amplified volatility in software, IT and several Asian tech names.
keyPoints: Specific Asia-Pacific tech names were hit amid AI fears — Japan’s Fujitsu and India’s Infosys both fell, echoing the selloff in U.S. software and IT stocks.
The partial federal shutdown delayed not only the January employment report but also the JOLTS jobs openings release that had been scheduled for later in the week.
About one quarter of the S&P 500 (roughly 25%) was due to report quarterly results that week, underscoring the heavy earnings cadence driving markets.

stories.name: Melania Faces Backlash Promoting Film at Hostage Event
stories.summary: First Lady Melania Trump faced backlash after referencing footage from her new documentary while hosting freed American-Israeli hostages Aviva and Keith Siegel at a White House briefing on Feb. 4, prompting a reporter to ask whether it was appropriate to promote a film at an official government event. Sitting in the Blue Room, Melania said a meeting with Aviva was "captured on camera and available to see" in her film and defended the appearance, saying, 'This is not a promotion' and that the visit was to celebrate the hostages' return. Critics and social media called the moment a "soulless grift," with outlets and observers highlighting the on-brand non-answer seen in video of the exchange. The documentary — released Jan. 30, 2026 — has been widely panned by critics, and reports about a large Amazon production and marketing spend have reinforced perceptions among critics that a government occasion was used to boost a commercial project.
keyPoints: Reports say Amazon paid roughly $40 million to produce the Melania Trump documentary and an additional $35 million to promote it.
Despite a 'solid opening' at the box office, the film has been critically panned, holding a 5% Tomatometer score on Rotten Tomatoes.
The documentary chronicles the First Lady’s journey in the 20 days before her husband's 2025 presidential inauguration.

stories.name: Melania Documentary Faces Backlash, Profit Doubt
stories.summary: Melania Trump’s self-titled documentary, directed by Brett Ratner, was acquired by Amazon‑MGM in a reported $40 million deal and premiered in late January with a wide roll-out in early February, chronicling her role in the run-up to Donald Trump’s second inauguration. Reports place production costs at roughly $75 million, and despite a roughly $7 million opening weekend — strong for a documentary — that appears insufficient to cover the reported acquisition, production and marketing expenses, leaving theatrical profitability doubtful. Critics overwhelmingly panned the film as a tightly controlled PR piece, and its Rotten Tomatoes and IMDb scores plunged into the low single digits and about 1.1–1.3, respectively. Conservative supporters celebrated some screenings and urged awards, while social-media users and other outlets ridiculed claims of packed, cheering theaters as exaggerated. The release also sparked controversy after Melania appeared to reference documentary footage during an official White House meeting with recently freed hostages, prompting questions about using government events to spotlight a personal project.
keyPoints: At an official White House meeting with recently freed hostages Aviva and Keith Siegel, Melania Trump explicitly referenced the documentary — saying the meeting “is captured on camera and available to see in my new film, ‘Melania.’” Keith Siegel also congratulated her, saying, “So much looking forward to seeing it.”

There are conflicting reports about how much Amazon‑MGM paid: some outlets cited a $40 million acquisition/funding figure tied to Amazon/Bezos, while other reports say Amazon‑MGM paid $75 million (a figure also reported as the film’s production cost).

Fox‑aligned commentator Kayleigh McEnany claimed theaters were “packed” and “standing room only,” saying “People were cheering... it was just electric,” a clip of which was widely circulated (viewed more than 5 million times on X) and mocked as exaggerated.

stories.name: Anker launches foldable 3-in-1 Qi2 25W Charger
stories.summary: Anker has launched two new charging products: the Prime 3‑in‑1 Foldable Wireless Charging Station and a 140W, 4‑port GaN USB‑C laptop charger. The Prime station is a compact, foldable MagSafe‑compatible 3‑in‑1 that delivers up to 25W Qi2.2 wireless charging for iPhone, includes a pop‑out Apple Watch puck and a third pad for earbuds, and uses AirCool active fan‑cooling to limit surface temperatures while sustaining high wireless power. Independent testing and Anker’s claims show near‑MagSafe performance—roughly 46–50% charge in about 26–30 minutes on recent iPhone models—while the fan is nearly inaudible and may improve charging consistency in warmer conditions. The Prime is available in the US now at $149.99 (with a $30 on‑page coupon on Amazon bringing it to $119) and comes in Phantom Gray initially. Separately, Anker’s 140W 4‑port GaN adapter offers dual high‑speed USB‑C ports (each rated up to 140W), ActiveShield 2.0 temperature monitoring, an HD display for status, and ships with a 240W USB‑C cable and an 18‑month warranty.
keyPoints: Anker’s 140W 4‑port GaN adapter can power four devices simultaneously, includes a 5 ft (240W) USB‑C to USB‑C cable in the box, and its ActiveShield 2.0 system monitors device temperatures over three million times a day; the unit also has a high‑definition color display that shows charging status, temperature, and port details.

The Prime wireless charger’s top half tilts up to 60° for a viewing angle, folds flat for travel, measures about 94 × 60 × 23 mm (~3.70 × 2.36 × 0.91 in), and its Apple Watch puck pops out with a single push and snaps back flush for travel.

The Prime includes an LED side touch control (white = fan off; double‑tap to turn blue and engage active cooling) and uses 'Cicada Wing' biomimetic airflow channels to keep the fan extremely quiet while providing AirCool cooling.

stories.name: Amazon reported launching generative AI tools
stories.summary: Building production AI products is less about novel models and more about robust data infrastructure and focused engineering: an Amazon listing-optimizer guide stresses reliable scraping, rate limiting, keyword tracking, and using professional APIs so teams can concentrate on differentiated features. Managed foundation-model platforms like Amazon Bedrock let developers build generative AI apps without owning GPUs or complex deployments by exposing multiple models through a consistent API. In production, evaluation and governance are critical: Amazon Nova’s LLM-as-a-Judge on SageMaker AI provides validated, model-agnostic workflows to assess generative outputs beyond traditional metrics. Operationalizing models is simplified with SageMaker AI Projects’ S3-based templates, which offer versioned, reusable CloudFormation templates, CI/CD integration, and one-click provisioning to reduce ModelOps overhead. And at the product level, experimenting by shipping multiple small, focused AI tools can accelerate discovery and allow teams to learn quickly and scale the winners while leveraging managed services and solid data pipelines to avoid infrastructure pitfalls.
keyPoints: The Amazon listing-optimizer guide recommends concrete engineering practices beyond scraping and rate limiting — for example, using connection pooling for database and API connections, tracking product-to-keyword relationships and average keyword rank, and ships production-ready code examples so teams can adopt them as starting points. The guide also recommends using professional data APIs (it names Pangolinfo) to avoid reinventing commodity infrastructure.

Amazon Nova’s LLM-as-a-Judge is presented as a rigorously validated, model-agnostic evaluator that claims to remain impartial across architectures, achieve leading performance on judge benchmarks, and closely reflect human preferences by leveraging LLMs’ reasoning capabilities to assess generative outputs at scale.

Amazon Bedrock’s framing of foundation models emphasizes their flexibility: the same foundation model can be prompted to answer questions, summarize text, create code, or rewrite material — illustrating why Bedrock exposes multiple such models through a single managed API so developers don’t need to operate GPUs or custom deployments.

stories.name: ICE Buying Warehouses for Detention Facilities
stories.summary: Federal authorities are acquiring large warehouses across the U.S. to convert into ICE detention and processing facilities, part of a broader expansion as the agency's facility count has roughly doubled amid a sharp rise in the detained population. Purchases include a $70 million site near Phoenix and an $87.4 million, 500,000+ square-foot warehouse in Berks County, Pa., and reporting indicates at least two dozen other warehouse deals are underway. Some transactions are reported to be in escrow with timelines suggesting facilities could open within months. Local governments and residents say they were often not notified and have limited legal recourse because federal projects are generally immune from local zoning; that has prompted actions such as a closed-door legal briefing in Surprise, concerns raised by Social Circle officials, protests and statements from Latino and Black legislative caucuses, and a moratorium in Kansas City. ICE and DHS have provided few public specifics but described the locations as "well structured detention facilities" and pointed to recent federal funding (the "One Big Beautiful Bill") to expand detention capacity.
keyPoints: Some warehouse owners have refused to sell to ICE after pressure from elected officials and advocates, and several cities have publicly urged ICE to choose other sites rather than local properties.
ICE senior advisor David Venturella described a reporter-observed tour of a 439,945-square-foot industrial warehouse in Orlando as “exploratory,” saying nothing had been decided at the time.

Pennsylvania Legislative Latino Caucus Chair Johanny Cepeda-Freytiz and Legislative Black Caucus Chair Napoleon Nelson issued a statement warning that ICE enforcement has caused “devastating consequences for families and communities,” citing family separation, aggressive raids and the targeting of people who pose no public-safety threat.

stories.name: Melania Trump Meets Freed Israeli-American Hostages
stories.summary: First Lady Melania Trump welcomed freed Israeli-American hostages Aviva and Keith Siegel to the White House on Feb. 4, 2026, and noted she first met Aviva in New York in January 2025 — a meeting that appears in her new film Melania. Aviva was held for 51 days after the Oct. 7, 2023 abductions and was released in a 2023 ceasefire, while Keith endured 484 days in captivity before his 2025 return; both thanked the First Lady and President Trump for their support. Melania said Aviva’s January 2025 visit, during which Aviva gave her handmade books about Keith, helped catalyze efforts that contributed to Keith’s liberation, and she passed the books and details to President Trump. Aviva, described by Melania as a “warrior,” and Keith expressed deep gratitude for the First Lady’s and the President’s roles in advocating for the hostages and supporting their families.
keyPoints: Melania Trump emphasized the Feb. 4 meeting was not intended to promote her film, saying, “This is not promotion... it's nothing to do with promotion (of her film 'Melania').”
The Siegels were abducted from Kibbutz Kfar Aza on Oct. 7, 2023, and Keith Siegel is noted to have grown up in North Carolina.
Aviva Siegel became one of the most visible activists during the war, advocating publicly for the release of all the hostages.

stories.name: DNA Linked to Missing Nancy Guthrie; Ransom Claim Unverified
stories.summary: Nancy Guthrie, 84, the mother of Today co‑host Savannah Guthrie, was last seen Saturday night at her Tucson home and was reported missing after failing to attend church; investigators believe she was likely taken against her will. Authorities found signs of forced entry, a blood trail outside the house, the Ring doorbell missing, life‑sustaining medication left behind, and said DNA recovered from the home has been linked to Guthrie; the FBI is assisting the probe. Multiple media outlets, including TMZ and a local station, say they received alleged ransom notes demanding a substantial Bitcoin payment with a wallet address and specific details about the home and Guthrie’s clothing, though officials have not verified the notes’ authenticity. Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos said no suspect or person of interest has been identified, detectives are interviewing anyone who may have had contact with Guthrie, and investigators are coordinating closely with the family. Law enforcement explicitly denied online rumors that son‑in‑law Tommaso Cioni is a suspect and urged the public not to share unverified accusations while labs and technology partners analyze evidence; Savannah Guthrie has taken leave from the Today show as the search continues.
keyPoints: TMZ reported it had verified the Bitcoin wallet in the alleged ransom note as a real on‑chain account; the note reportedly demanded payment 'in the millions,' included a deadline and a threat of harm if not met.
Tommaso Cioni — Savannah Guthrie’s husband — was reportedly the last person to see Nancy Guthrie when he dropped her off at her Tucson home on Saturday night.

Sheriff Chris Nanos said the three adult Guthrie children are 'leaning on each other' and are cooperating with investigators; Nancy’s children are Camron (a retired F‑16 fighter pilot), Annie (a writer and poet), and Savannah (Today co‑host).

stories.name: Retailers Fuel Budget Y2K Loungewear Revival
stories.summary: Retailers are leaning into a budget-friendly Y2K loungewear and apparel resurgence, offering low-price, trend-driven pieces and deep seasonal discounts. Amazon has rolled out versatile short-sleeve blouses starting at $8, Nordstrom’s Cold-Weather Sale offers up to 60% off winter apparel and footwear, and Boohoo’s DSGN Studio activewear delivers performance pieces from about £15. Velour loungewear gained renewed attention after Martha Stewart wore velour sweatpants, boosting interest in Juicy Couture and similar styles now starting around $31 with discounts up to 45%. The trend still spans practical performance legwear and fleece-lined workout pieces to elevated pull-on trousers, with retailers meeting demand across athletic, seasonal and professional use cases. Designer Kelly Wearstler has also shared travel wellness rituals — hydration with electrolytes and chia, pillows and a cashmere throw, and hydrating face and eye masks — highlighting lifestyle marketing around the apparel revival.
keyPoints: Amazon’s new short-sleeve blouses include wool-like options suitable for chilly weather and span styling roles from slimming/formal pieces to boho and workout-ready tops — the items are brand-new and noted as likely to sell out quickly.

Nordstrom’s Cold-Weather Sale highlights specific markdowns such as the men's Live-In Performance Zip Hoodie and Women's Aria 2.0 Platform Wedge Booties (reduced from $180 to $100), and also includes dozens of kids' clothes, accessories and shoes.

Boohoo’s DSGN Studio line features named pieces like a Piping Detail Funnel Neck Jacket (on sale for about £30) and an Ultra Sculpt Padded Vest Top, positioning the collection as performance-focused yet budget-friendly (prices from ~£15).

stories.name: Report: Companies Cite AI in 55,000 Layoffs
stories.summary: U.S. companies are increasingly citing AI as a factor in layoffs—outplacement firm Challenger, Gray and Christmas counted roughly 55,000 AI-linked job cuts in 2025, concentrated in the tech sector and in states such as California and Washington. Firms including Amazon, Pinterest and Dow have framed some workforce reductions as part of a shift toward AI and automation, though Amazon told employees AI was not the reason for the vast majority of its 16,000 corporate cuts and described the moves as organizational streamlining. Laid-off workers like Amazon’s N. Lee Plumb and some economists suspect companies may also be correcting past overhiring or using AI as a convenient efficiency narrative to signal value to investors. Opinion is divided among experts: some AI researchers warn of broad displacement, while investors and leaders such as Ben Horowitz emphasize historical patterns of automation creating new kinds of work and argue the future is unpredictable. Broader analysis warns the current wave of AI could mark a Fourth Industrial Revolution in which productivity and markets increasingly decouple from labor demand, raising hard questions about long-term joblessness and the sustainability of the social contract.
keyPoints: N. Lee Plumb, who was laid off from Amazon, served as his team’s head of “AI enablement” and was among the company’s top users of Amazon’s AI coding tool — and he is simultaneously running a long-shot bid for Congress in Texas focused on opposing tech industry reliance on work visas.

Challenger, Gray and Christmas’s chief revenue officer framed the dynamic bluntly: “That means jobs being replaced with artificial intelligence,” arguing companies face pressure to show efficiency gains after years of heavy AI investment.

Analysis describing a potential 'Fourth Industrial Revolution' highlights concrete market and labor data since ChatGPT’s 2022 debut: the S&P 500 has risen more than 70% while U.S. job openings have fallen roughly 30% (peaking at 11.5 million in March 2022 and dropping to about 7.18 million by August 2025) — a divergence dubbed the “scariest chart in the world.”

stories.name: JanAI Summit spotlights AI for rural India
stories.summary: India’s AI push highlights rural contributions to datasets, where workers label photos and videos for modest pay that supports families and brings new financial independence. Tech leaders like Infosys chair Nandan Nilekani say Voice AI could be India’s “next UPI moment,” enabling natural-language access to services across local languages. Political leaders are proposing capacity programs: Haryana’s chief minister has proposed a Haryana AI Mission with World Bank backing of about Rs 470 crore to build AI hubs and train 50,000 youth. Grassroots initiatives such as JanAI and the concept of “AI-first villages” frame a Digital Swadeshi approach to make rural citizens creators and co-innovators. Experts warn AI is neutral and will amplify strengths or expose weak leadership, so outcomes will hinge on training, infrastructure, values and governance guiding deployments.
keyPoints: Kamales Lardi warns that traditional command-and-control leadership breaks down in the AI era: AI doesn’t fix leadership and will instead expose weak leadership at scale, requiring new ways of working and leadership models rather than expecting AI to make decisions for leaders.

Nandan Nilekani made his remarks at an EkStep Foundation event in Bengaluru where NVIDIA was the technical partner; commentators noted the scale context—India already has nearly 500 million active UPI users and over 1.4 billion Aadhaar holders—underscoring why Voice AI could become a mass, default interface.

Haryana’s proposed AI plan specifies two regional hubs: the ‘Haryana AI Mission’ would establish one AI hub in Gurugram and another in Panchkula, with the World Bank assuring assistance of about Rs 470 crore and a target to train 50,000 youth.

stories.name: Valentine’s Day Guides Spotlight Purposeful Gifts
stories.summary: With Valentine’s Day approaching, gift options span from traditional jewelry to charitable purchases, playful games, handmade cards and campy art prints. UK small business Lily Charmed is promoting charm jewelry and themed pieces — including a silver heart charm, an adjustable “hug” ring, engraved lockets (currently discounted) and a starter charm-collector bracelet. In Singapore, CFS recommends buying from social enterprises like ART:DIS Studio, Artisan Collab and Metta/Metta-affiliated initiatives that turn artists’ work into scarves, bags and lifestyle goods while creating employment for persons with disabilities. Retail guides suggest toys and games as fun alternatives—featured picks include Lego botanical and heart sets, couple-focused card games like The Ultimate Date Night Game and We’re Not Really Strangers, plus family classics such as Candyland. Crafters can also make heartfelt, handmade cards using heart-themed dies, stamps and tutorials from makers like Concord & 9th, Penny Black and Spellbinders, while artist Jeffrey Aviles offers humorous, frameable Valentine prints sold via his website and Instagram as a queer-friendly, longer-lasting card option.
keyPoints: Lily Charmed’s silver “hug” ring is made from sterling silver, is adjustable to fit most ring sizes, and is priced at £60.
Lily Charmed is offering 25% off engraved pieces right now; engraved items can include up to 30 characters (including spaces) for a personalised message.

Lily Charmed’s charms use clip-on clasps that are compatible with other leading charm jewellery brands; the silver heart charm comes in both rhodium-plated sterling silver and gold-plated sterling silver.

stories.name: FDA Recalls Honey Supplement Nationwide Over Undeclared Tadalafil
stories.summary: The FDA and Akkarco LLC have voluntarily recalled the honey-based supplement Ashfiat Alharamain Energy Support after testing found undeclared tadalafil, a prescription erectile dysfunction drug. The agency said tadalafil is a PDE5 inhibitor that cannot be marketed as a dietary supplement and that Ashfiat Alharamain is an unapproved new drug with unestablished safety and efficacy. The product was distributed nationwide through Akkarco’s website and third-party marketplaces including Amazon. The FDA warned that unauthorized products containing tadalafil can pose health risks—such as cardiovascular complications and blood pressure changes—and advised consumers to stop use and consult a medical professional. Akkarco said testing found only a minimal quantity, has ceased non-prescription sales of the product, and consumers can report adverse events to the FDA’s MedWatch program. No confirmed adverse health events have been reported so far.
keyPoints: The recalled product is packaged in glass bottles with an orange label and specific identifiers: UPC 1234561870003, batch number ENCOT24 and an expiration date of October 2028.
The FDA had previously warned consumers in October not to buy the product, noting it contained “the active ingredient in Cialis.”

The FDA has repeatedly found undisclosed prescription drugs in supplements before — a 2018 JAMA study cited past agency findings that identified hundreds of dietary supplements containing hidden pharmaceutical ingredients.

stories.name: Amazon India partners IIT-Roorkee on crop-waste packaging
stories.summary: Amazon India has partnered with IIT Roorkee on a 15-month research project to convert agricultural residues such as wheat straw, bagasse and sugarcane residue into non-wood paper packaging that is recyclable and home-compostable. The lab-scale work will focus on producing high-quality pulp—using processes such as autoclave digestion, washing/screening and pressing/drying—and, subject to successful tests, Amazon will support progression to industrial trials and commercial production by mid-to-late next year. The initiative aims to cut reliance on imported virgin wood pulp, reduce stubble burning and associated air pollution, and create an additional income stream for farmers by providing a market for crop waste; India generates roughly 500 million tonnes of such residues annually. Amazon framed the collaboration as part of broader sustainability efforts in India, noting it ships over half of orders with reduced or original packaging and has eliminated single-use plastic in its fulfillment centers since 2019.
keyPoints: Dr. Anurag Kulshreshtha from the INNOPAP Lab (Innovations in Paper and Packaging) at IIT Roorkee’s Saharanpur Campus will be leading the research project.

Abhinav Singh, Vice President of Operations at Amazon India, said: “At Amazon, we are building and managing India’s fastest, safest, and most reliable operations network, and we’re committed to making it more sustainable... India generates nearly 500 million tons of this waste annually, and by repurposing it into packaging, we can support a more circular economy while reducing reliance on conventional materials.”

Prof. Kamal Kishore Pant, Director of IIT Roorkee, commented: “Sustainability is no longer a choice, it is an urgent national priority,” underscoring the institute’s framing of the collaboration as a national sustainability effort.

stories.name: ASUS ROG launches first open-back planar headset
stories.summary: ASUS ROG has launched the Kithara, its first open-back planar-magnetic gaming headset developed in partnership with HIFIMAN and positioned between audiophile gear and competitive gaming hardware. The Kithara uses ROG-tuned 100 mm planar magnetic drivers with an 8 Hz–55 kHz response and very low distortion, aiming to prioritize accuracy, separation, and clearer positional cues like footsteps and reloads. Its open-back design and rigorously matched drivers deliver a wide, natural soundstage at the cost of increased sound leakage, while an on-cable full-band MEMS boom microphone and separate signal paths keep voice chat clear. The headset ships with versatile cabling (including swappable 4.4 mm balanced, 3.5 mm, and 6.3 mm plugs plus a USB-C adapter) for use with DACs, consoles, and PCs. Availability has begun in the U.S., with outlets commonly reporting a $299.99 retail launch price though at least one review lists a $359 price, placing the Kithara between mid-range and higher-end gaming/audiophile alternatives.
keyPoints: The Kithara uses HIFIMAN’s Neo Supernano diaphragm and 'Stealth Magnets' technology, and is specified at 16 ohms impedance with total harmonic distortion below 0.03% at 1 kHz / 94 dB.
ASUS said it refined the headset’s tuning through listening tests with both competitive gamers and audiophiles to strike a balance between accuracy and enhanced bass for clearer battlefield cues.
ASUS originally unveiled the ROG Kithara at CES 2026.

stories.name: Amazon in talks for $50B OpenAI stake
stories.summary: Amazon is in preliminary talks to invest as much as $50 billion into OpenAI, which would likely make it the largest backer of the AI startup’s current fundraising effort. The discussions, led by CEO Andy Jassy working closely with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, come as OpenAI seeks up to $100 billion in fresh capital that could value the company near $830 billion, and SoftBank is also reported to be considering up to $30 billion. The potential deal would deepen Amazon’s AI strategy alongside existing multi‑billion dollar relationships—Amazon has large AWS commitments to OpenAI, an $8+ billion investment in Anthropic, and built an $11 billion Indiana data‑center campus to support large language models. Reports note Amazon is pursuing these external AI bets while also cutting corporate staff (figures reported in the press range from roughly 16,000 to about 30,000 since October), fueling questions about how investment in AI will intersect with workforce reductions. Multiple other investors (including Microsoft, Nvidia, Middle Eastern sovereign funds, and venture firms) are named as participants and sources stress the talks remain fluid with specifics subject to change.
keyPoints: OpenAI committed to spending about $38 billion on Amazon Web Services computing power over several years, a move that reduced its dependence on Microsoft.
Microsoft has invested more than $13 billion in OpenAI and holds exclusive integration rights through 2030.

If Amazon goes ahead with the reported up-to-$50 billion OpenAI investment, combined with its existing roughly $8 billion stake in Anthropic, Amazon’s total direct exposure to leading AI startups would be about $58 billion.

stories.name: Reports: Lauren Sanchez to choose Bond
stories.summary: Several entertainment reports this week have claimed that Lauren Sanchez — wife of Jeff Bezos — has become the decisive voice over who will play the next James Bond at Amazon’s MGM, with showbiz journalist Rob Shuter quoted saying “this is Lauren’s call now.” Those claims say Sanchez favors a Bond who is polished and “not carrying emotional luggage,” and that names like Jacob Elordi have been evaluated against that vision. Multiple insiders and the Daily Mail have pushed back, however, saying Sanchez is not picking the next Bond and won’t be a “Bond girl” herself (aside from a quip that she might be one for Halloween), and there is no confirmed change to the franchise’s official casting process. While Amazon’s 2022 acquisition of MGM raised questions about who controls creative decisions, longtime Bond producers remain involved and there is no independent confirmation that Sanchez has formal authority over Bond casting.
keyPoints: Showbiz writer Rob Shuter has previously claimed that Jeff Bezos wants Lauren Sanchez to appear as a Bond girl, describing Sanchez in crude terms as his 'buxom wife' who could be the next Bond girl.
The next Bond film (often referenced as Bond 26) is reported to have Denis Villeneuve attached as director and Steven Knight as the writer.
Amazon’s 2022 acquisition of MGM — the studio behind the Bond franchise — was a roughly $8 billion deal, which is the transaction prompting questions about who now wields creative influence.

stories.name: Amazon MGM Studio Plans AI to Cut Costs
stories.summary: Amazon MGM Studios has launched an internal AI Studio led by Albert Cheng to develop AI tools intended to speed up and reduce the cost of film and TV production, with a closed beta due in March and initial results expected by May. The lean, startup-style two-pizza team is primarily product engineers and scientists and will leverage AWS and multiple large language models to build tools that integrate with industry-standard creative software and bridge the "last mile" of production workflows. Amazon says the tools will streamline schedules and budgets (for example by improving character consistency across shots) while leaving creative decisions to writers, directors, actors and designers. The AI Studio is already working with industry partners, including producer Robert Stromberg, Kunal Nayyar's Good Karma Productions and former Pixar/ILM animator Colin Brady, and is inviting select partners to test and refine the tools. The effort reflects pressure from rising production budgets and comes amid a broader company-wide push to find AI uses following recent corporate cuts.
keyPoints: Amazon has cut about 30,000 corporate jobs since October and has pointed to the successes of AI as among the reasons for those cuts.
Amazon already has precedent for using AI in production — Prime Video’s series 'House of David' has infamously used AI in its production.
The AI Studio’s tools are being developed specifically to speed production for Prime Video series and feature films.

stories.name: Justice Department Releases Millions of Epstein Files
stories.summary: The Justice Department released a tranche of Jeffrey Epstein files comprising millions of pages and thousands of images and videos that link him to a wide array of high‑profile figures across politics, business and technology. Unsealed records show Epstein attended a private August 2015 Palo Alto dinner with Silicon Valley leaders including Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, Peter Thiel and Reid Hoffman — a gathering honoring MIT neuroscientist Ed Boyden and facilitated by Joi Ito — and internal notes indicate Zuckerberg’s team asked Epstein to share contact details. Elon Musk appears repeatedly in the records — discussing a possible island visit, receiving thanks for a SpaceX tour and being asked about SolarCity assistance — though he has denied close ties and called Epstein a “creep.” The files mention many other prominent names from Donald Trump to Bill Gates and proposed global guests such as Ngozi Okonjo‑Iweala and Emir Muhammad Sanusi II, prompting renewed public debate. Critics note the disclosure is partial and heavily redacted — reportedly about 3.5 million of roughly 6 million pages collected were released — fueling skepticism that the documents will yield new accountability. The records also include mundane and incidental items — restaurant refusals, UFC‑related references to figures such as Joe Rogan and the Fertitta brothers, and an attempt to buy footage of a Jon Jones fight — and some people named (including Jones and journalist Mehdi Hasan) say their mentions were purely incidental.
keyPoints: In an email Musk wrote he was “working to the edge of sanity” and, after the holidays, wanted to “hit the party scene in St Barts or elsewhere and let loose,” adding that “a peaceful island experience is the opposite of what I’m looking for,” a direct quote that appears in the released records.

The suggestion to invite Ngozi Okonjo‑Iweala and Emir Muhammad Sanusi II to an “out of the box” dinner with Epstein came in an email dated May 21, 2018, from Jide Zeitlin — then chairman and CEO of Tapestry, Inc. — who proposed them as two prominent Nigerian figures for a June gathering.

Reid Hoffman not only hosted the August 2015 Palo Alto dinner but previously visited Epstein’s Little St. James island in 2014 and had planned overnight stays at Epstein’s Manhattan townhouse; Hoffman has since apologized for his interactions, calling them a “major error” and urging full release of files to aid victims.

stories.name: Washington Democrats introduce 9.9% millionaire tax, bar referendum
stories.summary: Washington Democratic leaders unveiled legislation to impose a 9.9% income tax on annual earnings above $1 million, a change from the state's longstanding no-income-tax policy that backers say would affect under 1% of taxpayers and raise about $3.7 billion a year. The proposal directs revenue toward K–12 education, health care, higher education, human services and expansion of the Working Families Tax Credit, and would also eliminate sales tax on hygiene products and exempt very small businesses from the state B&O tax. Sponsors designed the bills as emergency legislation that would block a referendum, include a null‑and‑void clause that would void the entire act if a court strikes the tax, and set the tax to take effect Jan. 1, 2028. Gov. Bob Ferguson—who has previously supported the concept—said he cannot back the current draft because it does not return a sufficient share of revenue as tax relief for residents and businesses. Supporters argue the plan shifts the tax burden to wealthier households and has growing public backing, while opponents warn it could harm competitiveness and accelerate out‑migration of high earners and businesses.
keyPoints: The bills have formal legislative designations — HB 2724 in the House and SB 6346 in the Senate — and the text explicitly overrides Initiative 2111, the 2024 measure that banned state and local income taxes.

Because the bills are drafted as emergency legislation exempt from referendum, the only realistic path to undo them would be a full initiative campaign that must get an affirmative voter repeal rather than suspending the law via referendum.

The proposal includes a suite of narrow exemptions and credits — for family business sales and real property — and would provide credits for existing B&O, public utility, capital gains and pass‑through entity taxes.

stories.name: Microsoft shares tumble 10%, erase $357B
stories.summary: Microsoft’s shares tumbled about 10% after its fiscal second-quarter 2026 earnings report, wiping roughly $350–$400 billion of market value in a single session and marking one of the company’s largest one‑day drops since 2020. The company beat headline estimates—reporting $81.3 billion in revenue (up 17%) and adjusted EPS of $4.14—but Azure and other cloud services growth decelerated to roughly 38–39%, missing Wall Street “whisper” expectations. Investors also focused on a surge in capital expenditures—$37.5 billion for the quarter, up about 66% year‑over‑year—as management framed the spending as necessary to build “AI super‑factories.” Microsoft said its cloud backlog more than doubled to about $625 billion with a large portion tied to OpenAI, yet analysts warned rising AI-related costs could pressure margins and earnings momentum. The shock has reverberated through the broader tech-heavy market as investors increasingly demand a clearer near‑term path to profitability from massive AI investments.
keyPoints: Microsoft said it expects capital expenditures this year to top $100 billion, a figure that helped spark investor concerns about the scale and duration of its AI investments.
For the current quarter Microsoft guided Azure growth to a range of 37%–38%, below some of the 'whisper' expectations that had circulated ahead of the report.
Microsoft reported an operating margin of 47.1% for the quarter, and Microsoft Cloud revenue topped $50 billion for the first time.

last_30_days.name: Amazon MGM Asks Oregon Theater To End Melania Run
last_30_days.summary: The Lake Theater & Cafe in Lake Oswego, Oregon, says Amazon MGM asked it to stop screening the Brett Ratner documentary Melania after the venue advertised the film with cheeky marquee lines such as “Does Melania wear Prada? Find out Friday!” and “To defeat your enemy, you must know them. Melania starts Friday.” Manager Jordan Perry posted that “the higher ups” at Amazon were upset and that Sunday would be the film’s last day; the marquee was later changed to messages noting Amazon had called and that showings were canceled. Perry said he booked the film partly as a joke and to fill a slow week, but the decision drew heavy pushback from patrons, numerous emails and voicemails, and negative online reviews, and attendance was modest. The episode highlights tensions between a major distributor’s marketing control and a small independent cinema’s irreverent programming choices, and several outlets note the documentary has been controversial, costly for its distributor, and poorly reviewed.
keyPoints: Amazon MGM Studios paid $40 million for the rights to produce and distribute Brett Ratner’s Melania (reported as a 2025 acquisition).
Theater manager Jordan Perry warned the Lake Theater & Cafe might be put on Amazon’s “black list,” which he said could affect the venue’s access to future Amazon releases such as Project Hail Mary.

Reported production and marketing figures: Melania reportedly cost $40 million to make and $35 million to market; it earned about $7 million on its opening weekend and holds roughly a 6% score on Rotten Tomatoes.

last_30_days.name: Regional Roundup: Forums, Legislation, Fisheries Decline
last_30_days.summary: Rep. David Rouzer (R‑NC) will host his annual U.S. Service Academy Information Forum on April 25 in Southport to guide Seventh District students, parents and educators through the two‑step nomination and admissions process; interested participants must RSVP by email. Alaska lawmakers returned to Juneau facing decisions on funding failing schools and state infrastructure and will debate Governor Dunleavy’s proposals on new taxes, changes to the Permanent Fund Dividend, energy development and public safety as they seek a sustainable fiscal path. The Indiana House approved HB1343 to allow the adjutant general to establish a National Guard “military police force” with statewide arrest, search and policing powers; the measure now moves to the Senate amid concerns it could enable politicized deployments. Recent sittings of the UK House of Commons covered a broad agenda — including Holocaust Memorial Day, youth unemployment, the British Indian Ocean Territory Bill, prison capacity, pensions, police reform and multiple ministerial questions — signaling active parliamentary business. Regional reporting republished in local outlets documents a long, steep decline in Pacific halibut with ecological and economic impacts on fishing communities, while major outlets continue to publish categorized political coverage accompanied by standard legal and market‑data disclaimers.
keyPoints: Rep. David Rouzer’s forum will open registration at 9 a.m. with the program from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. and will be held at the Brunswick Energy and Education Center, 8520 River Road SE, Southport; representatives from all five U.S. service academies — including the U.S. Coast Guard Academy — will attend.

U.S. Sens. Thom Tillis (R‑N.C.) and Richard Blumenthal (D‑Conn.) recently introduced the bipartisan National Law Enforcement Officers Remembrance, Support and Community Outreach Act to create a formal Interior Department program to support community outreach, public education and officer safety/wellness initiatives via grants to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund.

House Bill 1343, which passed the Indiana House and now goes to the Senate, explicitly authorizes the adjutant general to establish a National Guard “military police force” whose members may carry firearms and exercise statewide arrest, search and other police powers — a provision critics warn could enable politicized deployments.

last_30_days.name: Pinterest Fires Engineers Over Layoff Tracker Amid Cuts
last_30_days.summary: Pinterest announced plans to cut about 15% of its workforce—roughly 700 roles—as part of a restructuring to reallocate resources to AI-focused teams, shrink office space, with changes expected to be completed by Sept. 30. Leadership declined to publish a broad list of affected employees, citing privacy concerns. Two engineers wrote scripts that monitored internal tools such as Slack to flag deactivated accounts and shared the results; Pinterest said they improperly accessed confidential information, violated policy and breached colleagues’ privacy, and the company fired them. CEO Bill Ready defended the dismissals at a companywide town hall, calling the actions “obstructionist” while saying healthy dissent is welcome but there is a line for conduct that undermines the company. The incident has provoked debate over transparency and employee rights and has been framed as emblematic of a broader shift toward employer control amid AI-driven job cuts in the tech industry.
keyPoints: Pinterest told investors the restructuring will cost between $35 million and $45 million, according to an 8‑K filing.
Pinterest said investment in AI-related headcount contributed to a 15% year‑over‑year increase in non‑GAAP operating expenses, an increase of about $543 million.

At the companywide town hall, CEO Bill Ready told employees they should consider looking for another job if they are 'working against the direction of the company,' framing the firings as necessary amid a 'critical moment.'

last_30_days.name: AT&T, Amazon Forge Nationwide Satellite-Fiber Network
last_30_days.summary: On Feb. 4, 2026 AT&T and Amazon announced a strategic “fiber-to-space” partnership pairing AT&T’s terrestrial fiber and customer relationships with Amazon Leo satellite connectivity and deep integration of AWS cloud services. The agreement will migrate major AT&T workloads to AWS hybrid cloud (including AWS Outposts), link AWS data centers with high-capacity AT&T fiber, and use Amazon Leo to expand fixed broadband and enterprise services while boosting resilience for FirstNet public-safety connectivity. The companies say the combined connectivity-plus-compute model is designed to eliminate domestic dead zones and support advanced AI applications at scale, positioning the alliance as a counterweight to SpaceX’s Starlink. The announcement rattled niche satellite-to-phone providers—AST SpaceMobile and Globalstar shares dropped sharply—and both firms said they will provide more details at Mobile World Congress in early March. Amazon Leo is also preparing a 32‑satellite launch with Arianespace targeted for Feb. 12 to help build out the constellation that will underpin the deal.
keyPoints: AT&T plans to use Amazon’s Q Developer AI software to expedite the migration of some workloads to AWS as part of the partnership.

AT&T Business Senior Vice President Shawn Hakl said, “By pairing our expanding fiber infrastructure with AWS’s cloud capabilities, and through our collaboration to deliver the infrastructure of the future by connecting data centers, we’re creating a more resilient, scalable, and intelligent connectivity ecosystem.”
Amazon Leo is the rebranded commercial wing of Project Kuiper and operates as a separate Amazon business unit.

last_30_days.name: Will Arnett Says SmartLess Cut Famous Comedian
last_30_days.summary: Will Arnett said on The Romesh Ranganathan Show on Jan. 26 that he and his SmartLess co‑hosts Jason Bateman and Sean Hayes recently cut a 'very famous comedian' after roughly 10 minutes of recording, calling the guest a 'f---ing rank a--hole.' Arnett declined to name the comedian on air, joking listeners would be 'blown away' and quipping, 'How did you get Bill Cosby!' He also described a separate episode in which a female comedian asked them not to air her already‑recorded appearance because she was 'up‑and‑coming,' a request the hosts weighed against production costs. Arnett's remarks have prompted online speculation about the guests' identities and follow recent SmartLess friction, including criticism of a Jason Bateman exchange with Charli XCX about having children. Launched in 2020, SmartLess remains a top‑ranked, Golden Globe‑nominated podcast with major distribution deals and industry recognition, which helps explain why discarded episodes and guest drama draw attention.
keyPoints: SmartLess was ranked sixth in the U.S. by Apple in 2025, placing it among the most‑listened podcasts nationally.

In 2023 the hosts and SmartLess Media struck a reported $100 million deal with SiriusXM that granted the company exclusive rights for three years to distribute and sell ads for the podcast and other SmartLess Media programs.
SmartLess was nominated in the Golden Globes' inaugural best podcast category but lost to Good Hang With Amy Poehler.

last_30_days.name: Fallout Finale Reveals Major Lore; Season 3 Confirmed
last_30_days.summary: The Fallout Season 2 finale resolved several major arcs and delivered key revelations: Hank (Kyle MacLachlan) is exposed as the architect of Shady Sands’ destruction and the creator of a brainwave-control device, and Overseer Steph (Annabel O’Hagan) is revealed as his pre-war wife and Enclave liaison. Hank ultimately activates the apparatus on himself, erasing his memories, while Lucy kills the surviving politician whose head had powered the machine. The Ghoul restores Robert House, receives a Pip-Boy that directs him to his family’s cryogenic tubes—which are found empty except for a postcard to Colorado—and then strikes out on his own; elsewhere Macaulay Culkin’s Legate assumes Legion leadership and tensions between the Legion and the NCR set up a large-scale conflict. A post-credits beat reveals Brotherhood of Steel blueprints for Liberty Prime, explicitly teeing up a much bigger Season 3 threat. Amazon and producers have confirmed Season 3 is in pre-production with filming slated to begin May 1, 2026; meanwhile a Bethesda/Prime countdown tied to the show revealed only behind-the-scenes footage, not the rumored game remasters. Critics and fans largely praised Season 2’s writing and performances, though some reviewers found the finale narratively hollow or uneven.
keyPoints: Hank claims he successfully miniaturised the brainwave-control apparatus and says he has covert operatives scattered across the Wasteland who could continue his plan.
The politician whose severed head powered the machine is identified as Denise Welch; in her final moments she pleads with Lucy to end her life, and Lucy complies.
Fallout Season 2 became the highest-rated live-action video game adaptation on Rotten Tomatoes when it premiered, strengthening the series’ reputation as one of Prime Video’s biggest hits.

last_30_days.name: Amazon makes Alexa+ free for US Prime
last_30_days.summary: Amazon has moved Alexa+ (Alexa Plus), its generative-AI overhaul of Alexa, out of early access and opened it across the U.S., available on Echo devices, the Alexa app, and Alexa.com. The assistant is rebuilt on large language models from Amazon Nova and Anthropic to enable more natural, contextual conversations and “agentic” actions like booking restaurants, ordering takeout, scheduling rides, and managing calendars. U.S. Prime members get unlimited access to the full Alexa+ experience at no additional charge, while non-Prime users can try a limited free chat or pay $19.99 per month for full access—making Prime the cheaper path for most customers. Amazon says testers used Alexa+ roughly twice as much as classic Alexa and highlights deeper Q&A, planning, and multi-step handling, but some reviewers note that many of the most useful features are now behind a paywall and remain skeptical about how broadly people will rely on agentic capabilities. The rollout positions Alexa+ as a mass-market, LLM-powered assistant and a direct competitor to other premium AI subscriptions and upcoming assistant upgrades from rival platforms.
keyPoints: Prime members can enable Alexa+ simply by saying "Alexa, upgrade to Alexa+" or by signing into their Amazon account on Alexa.com — a voice-command activation path Amazon highlights for easy access.

Amazon emphasizes Alexa+’s integration with Amazon services and hardware — including Ring cameras — and says the assistant can help users get more value from Prime benefits like Amazon Photos, Prime Video, and Amazon Music.

Amazon Prime is priced at $14.99 per month or $139 per year in the U.S., making Prime a cheaper route to full Alexa+ access than subscribing to Alexa+ standalone; Amazon also offers a 30‑day free Prime trial for first-time customers.

last_30_days.name: Renters Reportedly Embrace Rent-Now Pay-Later Services
last_30_days.summary: So-called “rent now, pay later” services have grown as rents have climbed—nearly 28% over the past five years, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics—and many renters with uneven paychecks are using them to avoid front-loading the month’s housing cost. Companies such as Flex, Livble and Affirm typically pay landlords up front while renters repay in installments, which users say can ease monthly cash-flow problems for lower-income and gig-economy workers. Consumer advocates counter that these products often function like short-term loans, adding subscription fees and other charges that can amount to very high effective interest rates and deepen financial strain. The tradeoff is illustrated by a renter who paid a $14.99 monthly fee plus 1% of $1,850 in rent (about $33 total) to split his payments for convenience. With roughly 109 million Americans renting and many households classified as cost-burdened by the Census Bureau, the trend is raising questions about whether these services provide meaningful relief or introduce new risks that may warrant consumer protections.
keyPoints: The renter quoted in the articles, Kellen Johnson, said “It was an expense that I was incurring, but I went ahead as it was more convenient,” and the articles note he previously worked as an independently contracted delivery driver for Amazon and now drives for senior citizens in Sacramento, California.

The Census Bureau’s 2024 estimate cited in the reporting found a large share of renter households pay 30% or more of their income on rent (the definition of being “cost-burdened”), a condition the articles say makes it difficult for those households to save or invest for the future.

The reporting frames the roughly 109 million Americans who rent as roughly one-third of the U.S. population—about 33% of the country’s ~333 million people—underscoring how many people could be affected by these products.

last_30_days.name: Reports: Israeli fire kills Palestinians despite Gaza ceasefire
last_30_days.summary: Palestinian media reported that at least two people, including 3-year-old Iyad al-Rubaiya, were killed in Gaza—the child was said to have been hit by gunfire from an Israeli Navy boat in al-Mawasi, and 22-year-old Ramadan Dardouna was reported killed in Jabalia. Other people were wounded in the incidents, and Gaza’s Hamas-run health ministry said hospitals had received four wounded and the bodies of three people killed over the past 24 hours, plus two earlier deaths. The Israeli military has not commented on these specific reports, though it has previously said strikes are in response to ceasefire violations. Details remain unverified and accounts vary by outlet.
keyPoints: The body of 3-year-old Iyad al-Rubaiya was reportedly taken to Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis after the al-Mawasi incident.
The 22-year-old Ramadan Dardouna’s body was reportedly brought to Shifa Hospital in Gaza City after he was killed in Jabalia.
Some outlets additionally reported that a 40-year-old man was killed in the al-Mawasi incident and his body was also taken to Nasser Hospital.

last_30_days.name: US January Manufacturing PMI Rises To 52.6
last_30_days.summary: The ISM manufacturing PMI for January unexpectedly showed expansion at 52.6, well above estimates around 48.5. US futures rose modestly, with S&P 500 futures up about 0.3%, Nasdaq 100 futures up 0.2% and Dow futures gaining nearly 200 points, as investors shifted focus to a heavy corporate earnings slate. Earnings-driven moves included Eli Lilly jumping more than 6% in premarket trading after beating estimates and issuing upbeat 2026 guidance, Alphabet and Qualcomm ticking higher, while AMD plunged nearly 9% and Uber fell about 7.5%, with mixed results from Amgen and Chubb. Reuters noted analysts lifted earnings growth expectations to roughly 11% for the December quarter even as consumer confidence hit an 11½-year low and a partial federal shutdown delayed some employment data. Traders are watching upcoming macro prints — including the ADP employment report and ISM manufacturing readings — and concerns about AI-driven disruption have amplified volatility in software, IT and several Asian tech names.
keyPoints: Specific Asia-Pacific tech names were hit amid AI fears — Japan’s Fujitsu and India’s Infosys both fell, echoing the selloff in U.S. software and IT stocks.
The partial federal shutdown delayed not only the January employment report but also the JOLTS jobs openings release that had been scheduled for later in the week.
About one quarter of the S&P 500 (roughly 25%) was due to report quarterly results that week, underscoring the heavy earnings cadence driving markets.

last_30_days.name: Melania Faces Backlash Promoting Film at Hostage Event
last_30_days.summary: First Lady Melania Trump faced backlash after referencing footage from her new documentary while hosting freed American-Israeli hostages Aviva and Keith Siegel at a White House briefing on Feb. 4, prompting a reporter to ask whether it was appropriate to promote a film at an official government event. Sitting in the Blue Room, Melania said a meeting with Aviva was "captured on camera and available to see" in her film and defended the appearance, saying, 'This is not a promotion' and that the visit was to celebrate the hostages' return. Critics and social media called the moment a "soulless grift," with outlets and observers highlighting the on-brand non-answer seen in video of the exchange. The documentary — released Jan. 30, 2026 — has been widely panned by critics, and reports about a large Amazon production and marketing spend have reinforced perceptions among critics that a government occasion was used to boost a commercial project.
keyPoints: Reports say Amazon paid roughly $40 million to produce the Melania Trump documentary and an additional $35 million to promote it.
Despite a 'solid opening' at the box office, the film has been critically panned, holding a 5% Tomatometer score on Rotten Tomatoes.
The documentary chronicles the First Lady’s journey in the 20 days before her husband's 2025 presidential inauguration.

last_30_days.name: Melania Documentary Faces Backlash, Profit Doubt
last_30_days.summary: Melania Trump’s self-titled documentary, directed by Brett Ratner, was acquired by Amazon‑MGM in a reported $40 million deal and premiered in late January with a wide roll-out in early February, chronicling her role in the run-up to Donald Trump’s second inauguration. Reports place production costs at roughly $75 million, and despite a roughly $7 million opening weekend — strong for a documentary — that appears insufficient to cover the reported acquisition, production and marketing expenses, leaving theatrical profitability doubtful. Critics overwhelmingly panned the film as a tightly controlled PR piece, and its Rotten Tomatoes and IMDb scores plunged into the low single digits and about 1.1–1.3, respectively. Conservative supporters celebrated some screenings and urged awards, while social-media users and other outlets ridiculed claims of packed, cheering theaters as exaggerated. The release also sparked controversy after Melania appeared to reference documentary footage during an official White House meeting with recently freed hostages, prompting questions about using government events to spotlight a personal project.
keyPoints: At an official White House meeting with recently freed hostages Aviva and Keith Siegel, Melania Trump explicitly referenced the documentary — saying the meeting “is captured on camera and available to see in my new film, ‘Melania.’” Keith Siegel also congratulated her, saying, “So much looking forward to seeing it.”

There are conflicting reports about how much Amazon‑MGM paid: some outlets cited a $40 million acquisition/funding figure tied to Amazon/Bezos, while other reports say Amazon‑MGM paid $75 million (a figure also reported as the film’s production cost).

Fox‑aligned commentator Kayleigh McEnany claimed theaters were “packed” and “standing room only,” saying “People were cheering... it was just electric,” a clip of which was widely circulated (viewed more than 5 million times on X) and mocked as exaggerated.

last_30_days.name: Anker launches foldable 3-in-1 Qi2 25W Charger
last_30_days.summary: Anker has launched two new charging products: the Prime 3‑in‑1 Foldable Wireless Charging Station and a 140W, 4‑port GaN USB‑C laptop charger. The Prime station is a compact, foldable MagSafe‑compatible 3‑in‑1 that delivers up to 25W Qi2.2 wireless charging for iPhone, includes a pop‑out Apple Watch puck and a third pad for earbuds, and uses AirCool active fan‑cooling to limit surface temperatures while sustaining high wireless power. Independent testing and Anker’s claims show near‑MagSafe performance—roughly 46–50% charge in about 26–30 minutes on recent iPhone models—while the fan is nearly inaudible and may improve charging consistency in warmer conditions. The Prime is available in the US now at $149.99 (with a $30 on‑page coupon on Amazon bringing it to $119) and comes in Phantom Gray initially. Separately, Anker’s 140W 4‑port GaN adapter offers dual high‑speed USB‑C ports (each rated up to 140W), ActiveShield 2.0 temperature monitoring, an HD display for status, and ships with a 240W USB‑C cable and an 18‑month warranty.
keyPoints: Anker’s 140W 4‑port GaN adapter can power four devices simultaneously, includes a 5 ft (240W) USB‑C to USB‑C cable in the box, and its ActiveShield 2.0 system monitors device temperatures over three million times a day; the unit also has a high‑definition color display that shows charging status, temperature, and port details.

The Prime wireless charger’s top half tilts up to 60° for a viewing angle, folds flat for travel, measures about 94 × 60 × 23 mm (~3.70 × 2.36 × 0.91 in), and its Apple Watch puck pops out with a single push and snaps back flush for travel.

The Prime includes an LED side touch control (white = fan off; double‑tap to turn blue and engage active cooling) and uses 'Cicada Wing' biomimetic airflow channels to keep the fan extremely quiet while providing AirCool cooling.

last_30_days.name: Amazon reported launching generative AI tools
last_30_days.summary: Building production AI products is less about novel models and more about robust data infrastructure and focused engineering: an Amazon listing-optimizer guide stresses reliable scraping, rate limiting, keyword tracking, and using professional APIs so teams can concentrate on differentiated features. Managed foundation-model platforms like Amazon Bedrock let developers build generative AI apps without owning GPUs or complex deployments by exposing multiple models through a consistent API. In production, evaluation and governance are critical: Amazon Nova’s LLM-as-a-Judge on SageMaker AI provides validated, model-agnostic workflows to assess generative outputs beyond traditional metrics. Operationalizing models is simplified with SageMaker AI Projects’ S3-based templates, which offer versioned, reusable CloudFormation templates, CI/CD integration, and one-click provisioning to reduce ModelOps overhead. And at the product level, experimenting by shipping multiple small, focused AI tools can accelerate discovery and allow teams to learn quickly and scale the winners while leveraging managed services and solid data pipelines to avoid infrastructure pitfalls.
keyPoints: The Amazon listing-optimizer guide recommends concrete engineering practices beyond scraping and rate limiting — for example, using connection pooling for database and API connections, tracking product-to-keyword relationships and average keyword rank, and ships production-ready code examples so teams can adopt them as starting points. The guide also recommends using professional data APIs (it names Pangolinfo) to avoid reinventing commodity infrastructure.

Amazon Nova’s LLM-as-a-Judge is presented as a rigorously validated, model-agnostic evaluator that claims to remain impartial across architectures, achieve leading performance on judge benchmarks, and closely reflect human preferences by leveraging LLMs’ reasoning capabilities to assess generative outputs at scale.

Amazon Bedrock’s framing of foundation models emphasizes their flexibility: the same foundation model can be prompted to answer questions, summarize text, create code, or rewrite material — illustrating why Bedrock exposes multiple such models through a single managed API so developers don’t need to operate GPUs or custom deployments.

last_30_days.name: ICE Buying Warehouses for Detention Facilities
